And weâ€™re going to work with the commission to try and identify what those dates are. â€œBut weâ€™re not going to fall to Hillary Clinton and the ploy that she did against Bernie Sanders of trying to have the audience. We want the biggest. â€ The Republican National Committee chair, Reince Priebus, also said the GOP was â€œgoing to be working with the commissionâ€ and said Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday nights would attract more viewers. Speaking to CBSâ€™s Face the Nation, Priebus said: â€œWeâ€™re not going to agree with anything that our nominee doesnâ€™t agree with. â€

author: NA
text: Philippine troops on Saturday dug up what they believe is the body of the Canadian hostage Robert Hall, who was beheaded by Abu Sayyaf extremists more than two weeks ago after a ransom deadline lapsed. Villagers led the troops to a hinterland near Kamuntayan village in Sulu provinceâ€™s Talipao town, where the militants buried Hallâ€™s body after killing him on 13 June. Hallâ€™s head was found outside a Roman Catholic cathedral, the regional military spokesman Maj Filemon Tan said. Tan said chances were high that the body recovered on Saturday was Hallâ€™s, citing intelligence reports and help from villagers. Police forensic experts would confirm the identity, he said. Hall was kidnapped with another Canadian, John Ridsdel, Norwegian Kjartan Sikkengstad and Filipino Marites Flor in September last year in a resort on Samal Island, also in the south, and taken by boat to Sulu, a predominantly Muslim and impoverished province 590 miles south of Manila. Ridsdel was also beheaded, Sikkengstad remains in Abu Sayyaf custody and Flor has been freed. Justin Trudeau, the Canadian prime minister, condemned the killings and called on other nations not to pay ransoms if their citizens were abducted, to discourage the militants from carrying out more ransom kidnappings. Philippine troops have been carrying out an offensive that has killed dozens of militants in Sulu. The Abu Sayyaf, which has more than 400 armed fighters, is blacklisted by the US and the Philippines as a terrorist group for bombings, kidnappings for ransom, beheadings and extortion. The militants have been weakened by years of battle setbacks but remain a national security threat.

author: Aki Peritz
text: The weekendâ€™s seemingly disjointed events â€” a bombing in New York City, several unexploded bombs discovered in New Jersey, multiple stabbings in a mall in Minnesota â€” has set Americans on edge again. It remains unclear if these acts were part of a grand international conspiracy, or whether a cell or single individuals are behind them. Yet what we do know is that we now inhabit an age in which itâ€™s logistically straightforward to commit attacks designed to kill and create mayhem, and there are clear ideological rationales for doing so. This toxic combination, along with an occasional willingness to die while carrying out the â€œoperationâ€ makes this new foe â€” call him a terrorist or a disturbed individual â€” particularly difficult to thwart. It used to take some degree of preparation to carry off a successful attack, especially in the west. The fact that some bombs in New Jersey and one in Manhattan failed to explode is a reminder that building explosives takes some degree of skill if youâ€™re to be successful. Also, convincing your radical comrades to engage in a conspiracy opens you up to penetration by the cops or intelligence services. That is an additional challenge. But stabbing people in a mall or shooting people in a club requires little preparation. You donâ€™t need any particular specialized training anymore except to pull a trigger, drive a car, be willing to kill and desire to be killed. Weâ€™ve seen this DIY violence elsewhere. For example, the atrocity in Nice, France, killed over 80 people, and while multiple suspects were arrested following the attack only one person carried out the operation. In this instance the assailant, Mohamed drove a large truck into a crowd, crushing scores of people. The carnage only stopped after police shot him dead. Soft, crowded targets are plentiful in our free, open societies. There is little the authorities can do to keep a determined attacker from striking pedestrians enjoying a balmy Saturday night in New York City. Guns, gates and guards can only provide so much protection against a wily, creative adversary who is willing to risk oblivion. What makes confronting these DIY terrorists even more difficult is that thereâ€™s an organization actively and successfully disseminating a message: the Islamic State. Through its slick social media messaging and global network of personal connections, this organization has been convincing the misguided â€” some of whom are lone wolves â€” to cause havoc in their home countries. This is no accident, but a plan terror operations outside Iraq and Syria have and will always be part and parcel of the Islamic Stateâ€™s DNA. For those who wanted to kill people more generally for their own reasons, Islamic State provides them a rationale by which to do so. For example, the San Bernardino killer Syed Rizwan Farook bought his weapons years before he killed 14 people at a holiday party. Why didnâ€™t he commit his crime earlier? We wonâ€™t ever know, since he (along with his wife, Tashfeen Malik) is dead, but perhaps Islamic State appears to have given him a reason and a mission to finally take the plunge and destroy himself. As long as Islamic State steadfastly pursues its â€œvictoryâ€ narrative, so long as it survives in one physical form or another, people will use its existence as a warped rationale for murderous behavior. Destroying Islamic State and draining the swamp will go a long way to denting the ideological allure of attacking civilians. At the time of writing, we still donâ€™t quite know the motivations of the NYC bomber or the Minnesota stabber. But we do know that if they were motivated by a jihadist ideology, crushing Islamic State will go a long way to reducing the rationale for this kind of behavior, making our streets safer. This will require sacrifice and great political capital to see it through to the end. Islamic State is fully committed to this conflict, will give no quarter, and will continue to use its power to cause havoc on our streets. Western nations must be committed to defeating Isis. In the meantime, our societies must be resilient enough to absorb â€œinspiredâ€ or â€œdirectedâ€ attacks from the Islamic state and its DIY acolytes for the foreseeable future.

author: Brian Moylan
text: Whatâ€™s the name of this show? The Good Place, When does it premiere? There is a premiere on Monday 19 September at 10pm ET right after The Voice so it can get plenty of attention. Then it settles into its regular time slot on Thursday at 8. 30pm ET, right after Superstore. Oh man, NBC Thursday comedies have sucked lately. Yes, they sure have. The network went broad and in a bid to be CBS and grab some of that Big Bang Theory syndication cash. But that didnâ€™t work (RIP Sean Saves the World) so The Good Place is a return to form of those great Thursdays of years past when 30 Rock, Parks and Recreation and The Office would rule. Mike Schur, who worked on both The Office and Parks and Rec, created this show. So, what is The Good Place? Itâ€™s heaven, silly. Eleanor Shellstrop (Kristen Bell) dies â€” sheâ€™s hit by a billboard truck advertising an erectile dysfunction drug â€” and winds up in heaven. The problem is those at the pearly gates think that she is Eleanor Shellstrop, a selfless attorney who got innocent men off death row, but she is really Eleanor Shellstrop, a selfish jerk who sold fake medicine to elderly people. Is heaven a bunch of fluffy clouds with angels playing lyres? No, heaven looks sort of like a very spiffy suburban strip mall with countless frozen yogurt stores, restaurants with punny names (The Good Plates) and, seemingly, an endless supply of stores selling cardigans and bow ties. Everyones lives in tacky McMansions that you say you would never live in but you totally would if given the chance. This is just one â€œneighborhoodâ€ of heaven and this oneâ€™s architect is Michael (Ted Danson) an angel who has been apprenticing for 200 years and this is his first solo project. Each person who gets to heaven is also awarded a soulmate. Eleanorâ€™s is Chidi (William Jackson Harper) a Nigerian ethics professor who canâ€™t decide whether he should help Eleanor stay in The Good Place or send her downstairs. What happens when this bad girl gets into heaven? She literally breaks it. When she steals shrimp from a party, the finely calibrated divine mechanism of eternity is broken and it results in her neighborhood being attacked by giant flying shrimp. Yes, super gross. Whatâ€™s great about this construction is that it allows for Eleanorâ€™s bad behavior to have immediate and disastrous results, only amplifying how horrible she is and leading her on a path to correct it. This is a great engine for a sitcom because the consequences are extreme and the fixes easy and predicated on being good so that everyone can hug their kids and tell them the world is beautiful before sending them off to bed. Is it funny? Just imagine a woman whose favorite book is Kendall Jennerâ€™s Instagram living in a neighborhood with 322 of the most altruistic, giving, selfless people in creation. Bellâ€™s golden girl looks and devilish behavior are a perfect combination for this role (as is her wonderful comedic timing). Danson proves yet again why heâ€™s one of the best in the business as a hapless angel not used to being human and trying to cover up his errors before any of the higher ups get angry. The jokes let us have it both ways. We get to indulge the devil on one shoulder with Eleanor when she picks on the priggish Chidi, her snooty British neighbor Tahani (Jameela Jamil) or the stuffy customs of the in heaven. But then we also get to focus on the angel on the other shoulder when Eleanor gets her slapstick comeuppance for behaving abominably. Itâ€™s like all the drinking with none of the hangover â€” just like in heaven. Should I watch this show? Yes, you should. Itâ€™s not going to revolutionize television comedy, but itâ€™s a wonderfully sweet, confection thatâ€™s a little bit edgy but still has the wholesome values that will make it acceptable for the whole family.

author: Ben Child
text: The Eurospy era, during which French, Italian and German producers competed to see who could release the cheapest James Bond at the height of the suave British secret agentâ€™s success, may now belong to some deeply dubious 1960s belle Ã©poque, but 007 continues to have his imitators across the globe. Only this week, the makers of the controversial Valley of the Wolves saga, long considered a Turkish answer to Bond, announced plans for a new instalment about the recent failed coup against president Recep Tayyip ErdoÄŸanâ€™s government. It will see suave spook Polat Alemdar (Necati ÅžaÅŸmaz) helping to rescue the dear leader from his loathsome military aggressors. Alemdarâ€™s previous missions include the 2011 episode The Valley of the Wolves: Palestine, in which the spy travels to Israel. Once there, a local man threatens him by saying: â€œYou know you wonâ€™t make it out of our promised land. â€ Alemdar responds with disdainful, brio: â€œI donâ€™t know what part of these lands were promised to you, but I promise you six feet under. â€ Knock it if you like, but the franchise is about to enter its fifth movie and has already notched up three TV shows. Yet even Valley of the Wolves pales in comparison with other fabulously terrible offerings from around the world when it comes to ersatz Fleming lunacy. Here are seven to have you choking on your minimally mixed Martini. Released in 1981, the same year as the Roger For Your Eyes Only, For Your Height Only features 2 ft 9â€ martial arts star Weng Weng as the diminutive agent 00. His task is to defeat the perfidious villain Mr Giant, whoâ€™s trying to take over the world with technology, while romancing beautiful women almost twice his height. Featuring heroically shonky dubbing, Eddie Nicartâ€™s film is perhaps most impressive for the variety of techniques tiny 00 uses to take down his much larger opponents. These range from poisoned darts to a remote control flying hat (like a upgrade on Oddjobâ€™s famous Sandringham) and tiny, machine gun. But mostly he just creeps up unseen, thanks to his tiny stature, and chopping his rivals in the back of the legs. How do you get around your lack of rights to any of Ian Flemingâ€™s Bond stories, characters, or themes? Well, in the case of Italian producer Dario Sabatello the answer is to recruit Neil Connery, younger brother of then 007 Sean, as well as Bond girl Daniela Bianchi (Tatiana Romanova in From Russia With Love) and Bond stalwarts Bernard Lee and Lois Maxwell (M and Moneypenny respectively in the Eon series). Released under a flurry of unsubtle alternative titles, including OK Connery, Operation Kid Brother and Operation 007, Alberto De Martinoâ€™s movie pitches plasterer Neil (his performance entirely dubbed by an unknown American actor) as Dr Neil Connery, a plastic surgeon bizarrely recruited by a Lee (here named Commander Cunningham) for a mission to take down the evil THANATOS organisation. As if the Bond allusions werenâ€™t enough already, two of the main villains were played by Adolfo Celi (Thunderballâ€™s Emilio Largo) and Anthony Dawson (Dr Noâ€™s Professor Dent). At the end, Lee turns to his successful agent and shamelessly breaks the fourth wall by telling him: â€œOK Connery! You were almost better than your brother. â€ Notable for racy scenes in which Bollywood icon Akshay Kumar frolics with his glistening leading lady in a steaming swimming pool (while singing, naturally) Mr Bond also stars Pankaj Dheer as a apparently villain named Dragon, who boasts a luxurious pet moustache so substantial that it puts Blofeldâ€™s cat to shame. Dragonâ€™s uniquely cruel signature turn of evil involves crushing small children to death beneath a large steamroller: not to be put off, Kumarâ€™s Mr Bond fights back with lots of crooning and disco dancing. The movieâ€™s finest sequence features our hero being sung back to life by a gaggle of tiny kiddies after taking a beating from an enemy henchman. Quite why John fresh from the Lord of the Rings movies, felt the need to appear as an agent for evil terrorist organisation INTERR in this grubby 2001 spy spoof will perhaps never be explained. Part Austin Powers, part Charlieâ€™s Angels, Never Say Never Mind: The Swedish Bikini Team pitches the titular quartet of blonde, models as international crimefighters tasked by mysterious boss Mr Blue (Bruce Payne) with helping friendly governments and worthy private corporations in the fight against evil. The buxom Swedish Bikini Team first came to public attention in a 1991 advert for Old Milwaukee Beer, drawing complaints of misogyny. So at least they had something in common with Flemingâ€™s famous secret agent. When George Lazenby turned down the chance to return as 007 in a sequel to 1969â€™s On Her Majestyâ€™s Secret Service, he probably never imagined it would get this bad. Less than two decades later, the Australian turned up as veteran secret agent Drew Stargrove in the 1986 Never Too Young To Die. A John Stamos stars as the ostensibly Flemingesque lead, Stargroveâ€™s high school gymnast son who takes revenge following the death of his father at the hands of hermaphrodite villain Velvet Von Ragner (a leering, gurning Gene Simmons of Kiss). The bad guyâ€™s signature kill move involves penetrating his victims with a fingernail, a murder method known as â€œthe fingerâ€ and which sounds deeply unpleasant. Licensed to Love and Kill (aka The Man from S. E. X.) was in fact the second in a series of Bond spoofs based around agent No 1 of the Secret Service, aka Charles Bind. But for the 1979 instalment, Canadian director Lindsay Shonteff somehow managed to convince The New Avengersâ€™ Gareth Hunt to take the lead in a battle against sinister organisation K. R. A. S. H. (Killing Rape Arson Slaughter and Hit) its evil boss, the subtly titled Senator Lucifer Orchid, and a dozen nefarious female henchmen, one of whom fights Bind using nothing more than a pair of spinning boobies. Despite being ostensibly set in the US, the entire film was shot in the home counties â€” and it shows. Early on, Bind asks himself: â€œWhat am I doingâ€ and you have to wonder if Hunt was experiencing similar emotions. Maxwell and Lee went moonlighting once again in 1975â€™s From Hong Kong, With Love, this time seemingly appearing as M and Moneypenny in an early cameo, which must have gone down well with Bond rights holders Eon Productions. Yvan Chiffeâ€™s spoof stars the popular Marx French group Les Charlots as a team of spies tasked with taking down the villainous Marty, played by an Mickey Rooney. It was filmed mostly at the Shaw Brothersâ€™ studio in Hong Kong and features a shameless parody of the famous 007 gun barrel sequence in which one of the Charlots apparently shoots himself in the face by accident. Because blowing your own brains out is always hilarious.

author: Matthew Teague
text: Louisville took the blow like a champ: still on its feet. Fists up. Still jawing. On Sunday morning at 22nd Street and Muhammad Ali Boulevard, the Reverend Larry Williams stood before the congregation at Zion Baptist Church and prayed: â€œWe ask for strength for the family of the great Muhammad Ali. â€ He raised his voice. â€œWe pray that theyâ€™ll have such peace they can come in rejoicing!â€ Since word of Aliâ€™s death arrived on Saturday morning, people across the city have come together in public to remember one of the cityâ€™s sons and to boast of his triumphs over his greatest foes. Not Frazier, or Liston or Foreman. But racial discrimination. Cowardice. War. His funeral on Friday will reflect his multifaceted legacy it will be an interfaith service, open to the public, streamed live on the website of the Muhammad Ali Center. From former president Bill Clinton to sportscaster Bryant Gumbel to Billy Crystal, a constellation of eulogists will try to describe the elements of Aliâ€™s personality â€” the magisterial, the athletic, the witty. And it will be, above all, a Louisville affair. Before the service, Aliâ€™s hearse will drive slowly through the city streets to Cave Hill Cemetery. Ali arose from here â€” from a tiny pink house in Louisvilleâ€™s west side â€” to become the most famous man in the world. He wielded that fame like a left jab. By the time he finished, he had changed the Louisville of his youth â€” a segregated, provincial city â€” for good. â€œNot just Louisville. â€ said his childhood neighbor, Lawrence Montgomery. â€œThe world. â€ Ali started here on Grand Avenue, honing the irrepressible qualities that would carry him to victory inside the ring and out. Montgomery has lived all of his 81 years on the same block of Grand, and as he talked on his front porch his hand moved lightly from scene to scene, outlining ghosts: the site of the old tree, the path to the park, the young Cassius Clay, not yet called Ali. â€œHe was always, eh . .. braggadocious,â€ Montgomery said. â€œI remember him telling me: â€˜Iâ€™m gonna be the heavyweight champion of the world. You watch.â€™ And I just laughed because he was a skinny kid. â€ Listening to Montgomery is like listening to Ali himself, had Parkinsonâ€™s disease not beset him: the accent, the mannerisms, the eyes that always seem just on the verge of winking. â€œI guess that skinny kid showed me,â€ he said. As a man, Ali would always appear to move without effort, never straining, whether dodging punches or political blows. And some of that was temperament. â€œHe was always jovial as a boy. Always joking,â€ Montgomery said. But much of that quality â€” dancing, flickering â€” came only as the result of intense, physical and mental focus. Ali only floated like a butterfly, as he bragged, because young Cassius had plodded liked a mule. â€œI worked at the post office, and in the mornings I remember seeing him pull on his old hobnail boots,â€ Montgomery said. His hand traced a line down the street, following an invisible boy. â€œHe would run to the park and back every day before school. And when the school bus came he wouldnâ€™t get on. He would get his books and run alongside the bus. â€ Eight miles every day, before school. Then the old tree, and more running. â€œHe had. .. â€ Montgomeryâ€™s eyes roamed for a moment, while he searched for the perfect word to describe the running boy, and everything he became. â€œHe had dedication. â€ On the wall of his home, Montgomery keeps a note Ali signed to â€œmy first bossâ€. Montgomery had three children, and employed Ali to babysit them. His daughter Linda said she remembered the two parts of Aliâ€™s personality â€” the playfulness and volume, underlaid by quiet focus. â€œOh, he was funny,â€ she said. â€œHe made us laugh and laugh. â€ But when a boxing match came on the Montgomery family television, he would sit the children in front of it to watch, unmoving, studying, until the final bell. As the radius of the young boxerâ€™s reputation expanded, so did the ferocity of his opponents. On Grand Avenue people grinned and shook their heads, but hoped for his success. The city of Louisville and state of Kentucky, though, were more hostile. The Jim Crow laws were in full effect here, enforcing segregation in every corner of life. Thereâ€™s a story about Ali set in the early 1960s, after his triumph in the Rome Olympics. According to Ali biographer Thomas Hauser itâ€™s not true, and the Muhammad Ali Center presents it as a legend. But it matters that in Louisville repeat it with the conviction of faith: after his win, Ali was refused a seat at a diner, and in his disillusionment he climbed a bridge and cast his gold medal into the Ohio river. People here believe that story, polish and cherish that story, because it captures two things that are exactly true. Louisville, and the south at large, was an oppressive home for black people, who had not yet even secured the right to vote. And all of that â€” the established order, the granters of gold medals and diner seats â€” would be revealed as a fragile, opponent by Louisvilleâ€™s brash young man. He threw away more than medals, during the Vietnam war, when he refused to register for the draft. Boxing authorities suspended his license for more than three years â€” three of the most critical, profitable years in a young boxerâ€™s career. Years that, as far as Ali knew, would not end. He could not have predicted historyâ€™s eventual view of Americaâ€™s involvement in Vietnam. â€œTo be honest we all thought Muhammad was losing it,â€ his old friend Montgomery said. â€œIt seemed crazy. What is he doing? It since then we have come around to understand it was his passion. Peace. â€ As his radius expanded to encompass the globe, his paradoxical nature revealed itself again. The worldâ€™s greatest fighter had an underlying aversion to violence. On Sunday afternoon in a plaza outside the Muhammad Ali Center, a crowd gathered to place flowers, pictures, boxing gloves and trinkets at a memorial. One of them was Amal Salom, who was visiting from Iraq and wore a head scarf as she took photos with her iPad. She is 58, and said some of the first images she remembers beaming out from her familyâ€™s television were of Muhammad Ali in the ring. The sport astonished her â€” men pummeling each other â€” but she said her strongest memory of Ali was from 1990, when he visited her country. â€œHe came to tell my president to not make war with Kuwait,â€ she said. She was referring to one of Aliâ€™s least known achievements, and perhaps his most important. On the eve of the US bombardment of Baghdad, Ali spent time there negotiating with Saddam Hussein, trading stories with a man with an ego to match his own, without the underlying humor. After a week he brought home 15 US citizens Hussein was holding hostage, and delivered them to their families. â€œI remember he told us, â€˜Peaceâ€™,â€ Salom said. Lawrence Montgomery, Aliâ€™s his old friend and first employer, was right. Not just Louisville. The world.

author: Jon Boone
text: An Afghan woman made famous by a photograph taken of her when she was 12 has turned down a offer to suspend her deportation from Pakistan, a country she first moved to as a child refugee. Sharbat Gula instead plans to return to Afghanistan on Wednesday, where she will be hailed as a national heroine in a scheduled meeting with the countryâ€™s president, Ashraf Ghani. Gula, now 44, has become the unlikely focus of a tug of war between the Afghan and Pakistani governments following a backlash over her arrest in October and conviction for living illegally in Pakistan under a forged identity card. A court ordered she be deported after serving a jail term and paying a fine of 110, 000 rupees (Â£850). Ijaz Khan, an academic at Peshawar University, said the arrest and trial had caused â€œdeep embarrassmentâ€ for the government. â€œA lot of people are connecting the way she has been treated with refugees in general, who have been treated in a very way,â€ he said. Over the past year, Pakistan has dramatically stepped up its efforts to encourage the estimated 2 million Afghans living in the country to return home. Many refugees claim they have been harassed by police, who have used the crackdown as an opportunity to extort bribes. The campaign has undermined Pakistanâ€™s boasts about its generous hosting of one of the worldâ€™s largest refugee populations. Gula, who appeared as the â€œAfghan Girlâ€ on the front cover of National Geographic magazine in 1985, has been raising her four children alone after the death of her husband. She is in poor health and is being treated in a Peshawar hospital. At the time of the photograph, taken by Steve McCurry, she was living in one of the sprawling refugee camps that were home to Afghans who had fled to Pakistan to escape fighting between Islamist rebels and the Soviet communist government in Kabul. She was found again in 2002 by National Geographic and given a stipend to live off, although there has been controversy in recent days over whether she received all of the money. News of her arrest drew sharp criticism from some Pakistani politicians, particularly from parties representing Pashtuns, the ethnic group to which Gula belongs. â€œTargeting the most vulnerable refugee population has upset and embarrassed the people of Pakistan,â€ said Bushra Gohar, from the Awami National party. â€œSharbat Gulaâ€™s case has exposed the poor treatment meted to the Afghan refugees in Pakistan. â€ On Saturday, the government of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) the province where Gula was living and was arrested, offered to cancel her deportation. But family members said she had rejected the offer after initial confusion over paperwork a KP government functionary had asked her to sign that she thought was a hospital discharge notice. â€œIt was an oath and affidavit saying that she wanted to stay in Pakistan but we prepared a fresh application saying she canâ€™t wait to leave Pakistan,â€ said Naimat Khan, a relative who has been staying by her bedside at Lady Reading hospital in Peshawar. â€œShe was grabbed from home and sent to jail so obviously she does not wish to live here in Pakistan any more,â€ he said. The family allege that she was targeted only after a local police officer learned she had money from selling her small house in Peshawar. A grand welcome is planned for her return to Afghanistan, where billboards with her photograph have been erected. After crossing into Afghanistan at the Torkham border post she is due to fly to Kabul for a meeting with Ghani. An Afghan government official said she will be given a house. Abubakar Siddique, a journalist from Radio Free Europe, said Gulaâ€™s case had provoked deep anger in Afghanistan, a country where sentiment is already high. â€œThis is an impoverished, vulnerable woman, treated harshly and detained after living in the country for 40 years,â€ he said. â€œIt was seen as violating the Afghan notion of honour. â€ The crackdown on refugees has come at a time when relations between the two neighbouring countries are in a deep trough, with Afghanistan furious at Pakistanâ€™s refusal to crack down on the sanctuaries enjoyed by Taliban leaders inside its borders. Ghani has responded to Pakistanâ€™s pressure on refugees by encouraging them to cross the border with a â€œgrass is green in my landâ€ public relations campaign. Despite the warm words there are serious doubts the Afghan government can cope with the huge influx of people, in addition to the large number of people displaced by fighting within the country. million Afghans, many of them born in Pakistan, are expected to have moved to Afghanistan by the end of the year. Officials say the surge in numbers is due partly to the decision to increase the amount of money paid by the UN to those returning refugees who are â€œregisteredâ€ to $400 (Â£323) a person.

author: Megan Carpentier
text: Phyllis Schlafly, the founder of the Eagle Forum who died on Monday evening, is best known for her grassroots movement that prevented ratification of the equal rights amendment in the 1970s. But conservative women say that it would be a mistake to think of her as solely involved or interested in countering the feminist agenda. They credit her reach as spreading far beyond that, to empowering women in the conservative movement, many of whom now lead their own national womenâ€™s groups whose areas of focus have broadened to include â€œfree marketsâ€ â€œpersonal libertyâ€ and â€œfamily valuesâ€. â€œIt wasnâ€™t a womenâ€™ cause that she led,â€ explained Lil Tuttle, the policy director at the conservative Claire Booth Luce Policy Institute. â€œIt was a conservative cause. â€ â€œShe encouraged us to speak out and speak boldly,â€ Tuttle added. â€œShe was a uniter in a lot of ways. â€ Tuttleâ€™s organization works to â€œprepare young women for conservative leadershipâ€ and promote conservative leaders. Its board members include Donald Trumpâ€™s campaign manager, Kellyanne Conway, and Marji Ross, the president of the conservative Regnery publishing house. Its speakers bureau includes Bay Buchanan, the sister of conservative presidential candidate Pat Buchanan who, with Schlafly, forced the Republican partyâ€™s platform to eliminate all references to exceptions in 1996 and Lila Rose, the founder of Live Action who, with conservative filmmaker James Oâ€™Keefe, participated in a series of stings against Planned Parenthood clinics. â€œPerhaps it is part of her legacy that conservative women found their voice,â€ mused Tuttle. â€œShe certainly promoted activism. â€ Schlafly got her start in politics writing about and campaigning for conservative candidate Barry Goldwater in 1964 because of her interest in opposing communism, and gained renown when she turned a grassroots movement of conservative women â€” many of whom were mothers with little prior political activism â€” into a force that could not only credibly counter but defeat the ratification of the equal rights amendment. The ERA, which at one point had been part of both the Republican and Democratic party platforms and the culmination of decades of work by womenâ€™s rights campaigners, was just three states shy of ratification when Schlafly began her campaign against it in 1972. Galvanized by the US supreme courtâ€™s 1973 decision legalizing abortion in Roe v Wade, Schlafly and her volunteers began knocking on doors and delivering homemade baked goods to state legislators, claiming that a amendment to the US constitution guaranteeing women equal rights would force women out of the home and into the workplace, add them to the ranks of military draftees and combat veterans, institute universal unisex bathrooms and force everyone to perform marriages, among other then terrifying visions of the future. Schlafly won, defeating the ERA, but lived to see the US supreme court legalize marriage, the US military accept women in combat roles, Congress poised to require women to register for the selective service, and even the issue of bathrooms â€” the subject of her last published column â€” come to the fore. Nearly 60% of adult women now work outside the home, comprising 47% of the overall US workforce, and equal pay remains the top issue for working women, Americans tell pollsters. And though by the time Schlafly gained political prominence there were individual Republican women who had been elected to national office, her efforts led to the founding of the Eagle Forum in 1975, an influential conservative organization with active state chapters often led by women. Cathie Adams, who has served on the national board for several years and was the president of the Texas chapter of the Eagle Forum, said that Schlafly â€œwould look across America and lift us up into leadership rolesâ€. â€œIt was a wonderful place to go learn, and Phyllis Schlafly was a wonderful mentor,â€ she added, noting that Schlafly and the Eagle Forum taught generations of women how to lobby and advocate for conservative causes at the state level. But Adams, Schlaflyâ€™s daughter, and several other board members are now embroiled in two lawsuits with the president of the organization over the Eagle Forumâ€™s future and their continuing presence on the board. Adams doesnâ€™t plan to stop her work with the organization. â€œIâ€™m still a member of the national board for which Iâ€™m most grateful,â€ she wrote in a statement. â€œItâ€™s a position appointed by Phyllis Schlafly to continue her legacy into the future. â€ Charlotte Hays, who serves as the cultural director of the Independent Womenâ€™s Forum, acknowledged with an appreciative laugh that Schlafly â€œdrove the feminists crazyâ€. But she agreed that Schlafly pioneered conservative womenâ€™s activism on more than just womenâ€™s issues. â€œShe was involved in every movement of the Reagan yearsâ€ and not just opposing the issues championed by feminists. â€œShe was just absolutely indomitable, absolutely essential,â€ said Hays. The Independent Womenâ€™s Forum focuses on the issues of â€œfree markets and personal libertyâ€ and counted Trump campaign manager Conway among its board members until she recently took a leave of absence, and Lynne Cheney, the wife of the former among its board directors emeritae. In an interview with NPR, Penny Young Nance, the president and CEO of Concerned Women for America, credited Schlafly with her own organizationâ€™s success. â€œI stand today on her shoulders in that I have a national platform to speak about the life issue and conservative issues,â€ she said. The CWA considers itself one of the frontline organizations in Americaâ€™s ongoing culture war, promising to â€œbring Biblical principles into all levels of public policyâ€ by focusing on issues of â€œthe family, the sanctity of human life, religious liberty, education, sexual exploitation, national sovereignty, and support for Israelâ€.

text: Marlon Byrdâ€™s second strike with drugs cost him a full season â€” and maybe his career. The Indiansâ€™ veteran outfielder was suspended 162 games without pay by Major League Baseball on Wednesday after testing positive for Ipamorelin, a growth hormone releasing peptide. Byrdâ€™s lawyer Jay Reisinger said in a statement that Byrd tested positive because of a tainted supplement. Byrd wonâ€™t pursue an appeal, Reisinger said. â€œMarlon is devastated, but understands that he is responsible for the supplements he takes,â€ Reisinger said. Itâ€™s Byrdâ€™s second violation of Major League Baseballâ€™s Joint Drug Prevention and Treatment Program. Shortly after he was released in 2012 by Boston, Byrd served a suspension for testing positive for Tamoxifen, a medication used by body builders but also to treat breast cancer in women and men. In 2014, MLB increased its penalty for a second offense in 2014 from 100 games to a full season. A third suspension would result in a lifetime ban. In February, New York Mets pitcher Jenrry Meija became the first player to receive that sanction. Byrd, Meija and New York Yankees star Alex Rodriguez are the only players to receive suspensions. Even if heâ€™s able stay clean, at 38, Byrdâ€™s playing days appear over. He signed a $1m contract as a free agent in March with Cleveland, which needed veteran outfield depth because both left fielder Michael Brantley and right fielder Lonnie Chisenhall were recovering from injuries. Byrd has been productive, batting . 270 with five homers and 19 RBIs in 34 games â€” mostly against . He went 4 for 4 with a homer on Monday night against Texas, and then struck out three times in a loss Tuesday. He spent last season with Cincinnati and San Francisco. Byrd broke in with Philadelphia in 2002. He was an in 2010 with the Chicago Cubs, one of 10 teams heâ€™s played for. Following his first suspension, Byrd signed with the New York Mets in 2013. To replace Byrd on the roster, the Indians recalled outfielder Tyler Naquin from Columbus.

author: Megan Carpentier
text: People who live around Albany are used to having to explain that being from New York does not automatically mean that youâ€™re from New York City. It can be annoying to be constantly explaining that unemployment is lower, housing is less expensive, there are definitely more people than cows and it is, after all, the center of the stateâ€™s government, even if New York City folks believe theyâ€™re the center of the universe. But for many or fortysomething residents of the state capital, about 150 miles north of Manhattan, their student debt is still weighing them down, despite their having aged out of the twentysomething demographic that is the focus of public student debt sympathy. â€œI pay $700 a month in student loans and I didnâ€™t go to a fancy school,â€ explained Deanna Fox, 30, a writer who lives in Delanson, to a table full of people in their 30s and 40s gathered at the Riverfront Bar and Grille in Albany. â€œBut there really wasnâ€™t any opportunity as far as scholarships go: because I came from a very family, I was too wealthy â€” even though we didnâ€™t have much â€” to get a lot of grants or scholarships, and wasnâ€™t wealthy enough for my parents to pay for me to go to college out of their own pockets. â€œSo I had to take out probably 75% of my funding for college as a loan, and most of it was private loans. â€ â€œI also pay $700 in student loans a month,â€ said Emily Lemieux, a museum professional living in Albany, â€œand I also didnâ€™t go to fancy schools. â€ Young millennials get more attention for their student loan burdens, but students faced such hefty burdens nearly 15 years earlier. Most people in their 30s and early 40s went to college just as tuition rates began their meteoric climbs, and at or around the time when the federal government got out of the student loan game and turned over the origination of federally subsidized loans to private companies like Sallie Mae. These students entered the working world at either the end of the first tech bubble, shortly after in the middle of two wars or at the start of the Great Recession. This demographic is nearly as likely as millennials are to identify as political independents â€” especially in Albany, where about 30% of registered voters opt out of identifying as either Democrats or Republicans. Thatâ€™s about average outside of the New York City area. Anna Varney, a old account executive with the digital marketing company Overit, said: â€œI specifically went to [the State University of New York at] Albany so that I wouldnâ€™t have student loans, so I limited all of my life choices, in a way, because I didnâ€™t want student loans, because I knew that would limit me down the road. â€ Varneyâ€™s colleague at Overit, Jennifer Van Iderstyne, said, â€œThere has been this slow rise in the cost of higher education thatâ€™s really happened over the last couple of decades to the point where it was burdensome on those of us who were in school 10 years ago. Itâ€™s an impossibility for those who are heading into it now. â€ â€œWeâ€™re struggling to survive with those debts,â€ she added. â€œThey donâ€™t even have a chance. â€ Latham resident Ben Backes, 35, who works in biotech, jumped in. â€œThe cost of college over that 15 years . .. has kept going up, and so itâ€™s just like, it seems like youâ€™re paddling upstream and the current is taking everybody with it. â€ Fox was focused, too, on the opportunity costs of having to take out loans to fund her education. â€œI think about how I could put that money towards my own childrenâ€™s education I couldâ€™ve put more of a down payment on my house that I bought,â€ she said. â€œYou know, 70 years ago, people had limited choices but they also had more choices,â€ mused Fox. â€œYou could become a farmer and it would pay for your family. You could become a doctor and you wouldnâ€™t be mired down in debt for the rest of your life. â€ Lemieux said: â€œI just think about my grandpa, who went to world war II and he came back and he went to work at GM. He had six kids and his wife never worked, and they had a summer home, and that was like, their whole life was his job. â€ â€œCan you imagine having six kids on one income now, for somebody that didnâ€™t go to college?â€ she asked. â€œYou could have two people go to college and still . .. â€ She trailed off, the meaning clear to everyone at the table. But while almost everyone was in similar economic circumstances, Jeff Cutler, a software engineer who lives in Cohoes, New York, felt there were others to blame besides college administrators. â€œIâ€™m a bit later in my career than everybody else â€” I paid off my student loans, things like that â€” and Iâ€™m very concerned that the government is not working, or our politicians,â€ he said. â€œThey have some ideas that have been fed to them over the years that they double down on, they triple down on. And so itâ€™s really not addressing the concerns of average Americans. â€ Van Iderstyne agreed. â€œI believe that the absence of term limits and the existence of being a politician as a lifetime career, for many of these people, leads them to make compromised decisions that are not really in the best interest of the people or fixing our problems,â€ she said. â€œWhen you have half the government, half of our elected officials saying, â€˜We donâ€™t think government works, we want to get rid of government,â€™ how is government ever going to work?â€ asked Cutler. â€œI want it to work because Iâ€™m sending a quarter to a third of my salary there. I want it to work well!â€ One example of politiciansâ€™ failure to effectively govern is infrastructure, the group agreed. Van Iderstyne said: â€œI went to school at Suny [the State University of New York] Potsdam â€” thatâ€™s way up north, like, Suny Canada. There were, like, hundreds of miles up there that are basically inaccessible,â€ making it impossible to attract economic development that could sustain residents. Fox said itâ€™s not just physical accessibility that needs improvement. â€œThereâ€™s no internet, thereâ€™s no broadband, thereâ€™s no phone service,â€ she said. â€œPart of that you canâ€™t really help youâ€™re in the middle of the Adirondacks. But at the same time, I live 20 miles from here and I have no broadband. â€ â€œIt costs from a business standpoint I would say that the cost is prohibitive,â€ noted Backes. â€œBut isnâ€™t that why we have a federal government? To find some way to offset some of those costs, so that the people who choose to live in those areas, or canâ€™t afford to get out of them â€” which, back to the education thing â€” theyâ€™d have some options?â€ â€œThe fact is that it may not make sense, economic sense, to have broadband out where you are,â€ Cutler said. â€œHowever, from a standpoint of society, itâ€™s very important to have that there. And for America in general, actually, ultimately itâ€™s better for business â€” but the return on investment takes so long that a business might not be willing to do that. â€ And that brought Cutler to one of his biggest concerns when he hears people advocating for a businessman to run the government. â€œBusinesspeople have different concerns than what we need for effective government,â€ he said. â€œAnd the idea that a businessman will magically be able to solve all the problems â€” theyâ€™re not concerned about what the average person needs, theyâ€™re worried about numbers and profits and loss. â€ â€œThatâ€™s exactly it!â€ exclaimed Backes. â€œShort term! Everything I feel like Iâ€™ve heard this election cycle, and every previous election cycle is, â€˜Well, what are you going to do for me today?â€™ â€” because thatâ€™s whatâ€™s on most peopleâ€™s minds, because of their crippling debt. â€ He added: â€œSo the role of government, for me, is to have these visions and to be able to help that. â€ Fox added: â€œHaving a businessman? Businesses are the ones that are financing campaigns. And so it seems like the general American populace is completely eradicated from the political process besides pandering to get their votes. â€ â€œSo many of the problems weâ€™re talking about arenâ€™t really made or broken on the presidential level,â€ said Van Iderstyne. â€œThis is all in Congress. The president gets eight years, period, but your congressman can be there years. â€œSo whatâ€™s his incentive to take a pay cut or to enact campaign finance reform thatâ€™s going to negatively affect his ability to make TV ads the next time around?â€ she asked. â€œI donâ€™t trust any of them,â€ said Backes. â€œBut I donâ€™t cast my vote necessarily for the one I trust. â€œFor me, most of our elections really seem to come down to the lesser of two evils. The least of three,â€ he added. â€œEvery election comes down to that,â€ said Varney. â€œI feel like it speaks to the character of the kind of people who are now attracted to politics,â€ said Van Iderstyne. â€œAnd also what you have to be and what you have to be willing to accept in terms of invasion and living your life in a fishbowl. â€ â€œUnfortunately, it feels like the people who are the smartest people to solve those problems are too smart to get involved,â€ Fox piped up. â€œI think itâ€™s definitely become more polarized,â€ said Fox. â€œAnd I think that part of the problem, too, is that there hasnâ€™t been a unifying issue that people really connect over. â€ â€œYou would think the recession would have been a unifying issue you would think war against terrorism would be a unifying issue,â€ said Varney. â€œYou would think mass shootings in our schools would be unifying issues,â€ said Van Iderstyne. â€œBut theyâ€™re not. Itâ€™s too divisive. â€ â€œThereâ€™s two ends of that discussion,â€ said Fox. â€œThereâ€™s â€˜take away your gunsâ€™ or â€˜keep your gunsâ€™. Itâ€™s seems like thatâ€™s the only thing that people can focus on. â€ â€œItâ€™s so black or white,â€ said Backes. â€œItâ€™s not,â€ said Varney. â€œWe could have nuance. â€ Lemieux added: â€œIn a school shooting, everyone doesnâ€™t unify around getting a solution. Theyâ€™re opposite. And then we having nothing. â€
